Dear Chatham Families,

At Chatham Central School District, we are committed to providing our community with information pertaining to the COVID-19 situation and its impact on our schools. Today we were informed that one of our 10-month employees tested positive for COVID-19. It is important to note that this case occurred outside of school and that the employee had not been on campus this school year. Therefore, this case does not impact our school buildings or other staff members.

Due to privacy laws, we will not be identifying who the employee is. We appreciate your understanding of the situation.

As is the procedure for any confirmed positive case, the individual will not return to campus until cleared to do so by the Department of Health.

Please rest assured that protecting the health, welfare, and safety of our students, staff, and larger community is our priority. Questions or concerns can be directed to the superintendent’s office.

Fall Sports Season Delayed

As the state considers the reopening of schools, the New York State Public High School Athletic Association (NYSPHSAA) has delayed the official start date of the Fall, 2020 sports season to September 21. This means all fall interscholastic sports at Chatham will not begin prior to this date, and our fall sports registration period will also be pushed back.

NYSPHSAA also canceled the Fall 2020 Regional and State Championships and has announced that if school sports must be suspended throughout 2020 due to the COVID-19 crisis, it is prepared to implement a condensed Fall/Winter/Spring season schedule starting in January, 2021.

You can read the full release from NYSPHSAA here:
http://nysphsaa.org/Portals/0/COVID%2019/COVID%20Task%20Force%20Meeting%20PR%20071620%20FINAL.pdf?fbclid=IwAR14Jh9QstkeVS678peisXgzogRyexVSyjj9kYKIGxu9nPSrCksY9tzvjsE

Our athletic department expects to be able to provide our families with more information about our fall sports season in the next few weeks.

The Board of Education has adopted a proposed budget for the 2020-21 school year that totals $32,356,855 and carries a projected tax levy increase of 1.67 percent, which is under the 1.72 percent limit set by the NYS property tax cap. Spending is up a total of $773,465, a 2.45 percent increase from the current year’s budget.

"While the future is definitely more uncertain than in past budget cycles, we are confident our long-term financial planning and conservative budgeting practices have kept Chatham in a position to weather the storm for the coming school year, and we are able to do it in a way that keeps both our students and our taxpayers in mind," said superintendent of schools Dr. Sal DeAngelo.

The Budget Vote takes place June 9, with all voting by absentee ballot, per an executive order by Governor Cuomo.

More information is available at https://www.chathamcentralschools.com/district/budget-information/

Join the Statewide Thought Exchange on Reopening Schools

Dear Chatham CSD Community,

With our school motto being Everyone, Every Day, I want to encourage everyone to participate in a statewide thought exchange about schools safely reopening in the future. You will be able to share your thoughts and help evaluate important issues concerning students returning to campus. All contributions are anonymous and you will also be able to read and rate other participants' responses.

This is a statewide exchange facilitated by all of New York’s local BOCES (Boards of Cooperative Educational Services). The survey results will be shared with our elected officials to give them a better understanding of the thoughts and ideas our community has about returning to in-person schooling. The survey is open until 5:00 p.m. on Friday, May 29.

To participate, please follow the Thought Exchange Link: https://my.thoughtexchange.com/333518046 and select the Questar III BOCES participation group.

Thank you for your participation,

Dr. Sal DeAngelo

Superintendent of Schools

For her National Junior Honor Society service credit, Taylor VanWie is utilizing recycled glass bottles and lokta paper to create beautiful vases for area nursing homes. This week, she delivered several of her vases, filled with fresh cut flowers, to the Payn Home in Chatham for the residents there to enjoy. Her trip included participating in a community car parade that swung by the home in honor of resident Douglas Burgess' 100th birthday. Mr. Burgess is a U.S. Navy veteran who served in World War II and who, at our students' request, has visited CMS to share his experiences! We've included a photo of him from his visit in 2018.

Updates for 3-18-2020

Dear Chatham Families,

post_text: The CHS Outdoors Club (advisors Brooke Decker, Mike Kullman, and Rodney Stickles) took a hike to High Falls Conservation Area in Philmont March 5. Spring is certainly coming and the students had a great time on the hike. The High Falls Conservation Area is part of the Columbia Land Conservancy and home to Columbia County’s highest waterfall. The Agawamuck Creek and the resulting waterfalls played a large part in generating power for the mills that were once the main source of business in Philmont. Although the mills no longer operate, the beauty of the spot draws in many hikers. The Outdoors Club will certainly be getting back its love of hiking now that the weather is nice, with the goal of completing all of the Columbia Land Conservancy hikes by the end of the year. Any CHS student who loves the outdoors is encouraged to join them for a hike or two!

Their performance at MED was made possible by a grant from the Chatham Education Foundation of the Berkshire Taconic Community Foundation.

A special thank you to the Fine Arts Booster Club for their support in covering shipping costs for the portraits.

post_text: This week, our seventh graders conducted mindfulness exercises under the direction of CCSD’s psychologist coach, Dr. Anita Kilea. Mindfulness is a calming meditative practice achieved by focusing awareness inward and on the present moment to realize and accept one's emotions, thoughts, and physical sensations. Tuesday's sessions were born out of discussions with the seventh grade’s Key Communicator students, who suggested mindfulness as a way to overcome the anxiety they had about taking their first-ever midterm exams this week. In response, CMS counselor Jackie Hoffman arranged to have Dr. Kilea in the day before midterms began to lead mindfulness sessions for all seventh graders during their social studies time. Along with studying, getting a good night's sleep, and eating well, students could apply mindfulness techniques to prepare for a big test or any other anxiety inducing situation they may face.

Chatham Middle School’s National Junior Honor Society (NJHS) served up a holiday treat for area seniors today. Their annual Holiday Senior Luncheon is a long-standing community favorite – with 75 guests visiting the Middle School this year to enjoy music, food, and holiday atmosphere. The day began with a lively holiday concert in the auditorium, where the Grade 7/8 Band, Chorus, and Orchestra performed some selections from their upcoming Winter Concert. Then it was on to gymnasium where the NJHS students served up a turkey feast (prepared by our kitchen staff) along with some holiday fun - mood-setting music performed by strings students, a visit from Santa (eighth grader Dayton Harvey), and a game of bingo where the seniors could win prizes that the students had purchased and wrapped.

The NJHS Senior Luncheon is an award-winning service program now in its twenty-sixth year at CMS. NJHS members plan and carry out all aspects of the event, from designing the decorations, to raising funds to pay for the gifts and dinner, to personally inviting their guests.

post_text: Liam Drowne, a sixth grader at Chatham Middle School, is Chatham’s newest Spelling Champion. During CCSD’s Spelling Bee today, Liam correctly spelled “emphatic” to clinch the title and earn a spot at the Capital Region Spelling Bee held at Proctor’s Theatre in Schenectady on February 4! Eighth grader Lucia Bigelow and fourth grader Ava Lombardi were our co runners-up. The competition, streamed live from the CMS auditorium on December 12 for the world to enjoy, brought together our top spellers from grades four through eight. All the students in the Bee qualified for the competition by first winning spelling competitions at the classroom level. Congratulations to all our participants and good luck to Liam at regionals!

post_text: In 6th grade social studies, students are studying ancient history and have now arrived at the dawn of civilization, starting in Ancient Sumer. As societies became more complex, the need to create records arose, which in turn necessitated the invention of written language. The people who made early records were known as scribes and were important, highly educated people in their societies. Students experienced what it was like to be an ancient scribe by making “clay tablets” (from dough) and using “styluses” to write messages on them in ancient Sumerian cuneiform, one of the earliest known forms of writing.

post_text: Volunteer firefighters from local fire companies all over the Chatham Central School District visited MED November 1 for Fire Prevention Day. They brought along their trucks and firefighting gear to show the students and, during assemblies held in front of the school, shared what to do in the case of a fire emergency at home. They made Mr. Fortran, assistant principal at MED, an honorary firefighter by dressing him up in the firefighting gear they wear. The school then held a fire drill and after that, the firefighters went classroom to classroom to talk about fire safety with our students. Many of the visiting firefighters are Chatham graduates and parents. Special thanks to all our volunteers!

post_text: The CMS Service Club visited Camphill Ghent for their October service event. They cleaned out gardens, cleared roots for replanting, trimmed black-eyed susans, gathered seeds and replanted. Camphill Ghent is a residential community for senior citizens. Students engaged with some of the residents who shared their experiences as they worked together.
